column6: Notes
Banned for 25 years in Albania.[3]
Banned for 25 years in Albania.[3]
Banned for being "obscene".[4]
Banned in Australia from 1927 to 1936 and from 1938 to 1973.[5]
Banned by the Australian Government in 1957 for obscenity.[6]
Banned for obscenity from 1901 to 1923 and 1928 to c.1973.[7][8]
First edition published as a novel, second edition banned by the military censor in Australia under regulations of the War Precautions Act 1914.[9]
Banned from 1929 to 1965.[10][11]
Banned in Australia because of customs belief that it "lacked sufficient claim to the literary to excuse the obscenity"[12]
Banned in Australia from 1932 to 1937.[10]
Banned in Australia from 1933 to 1953.[13]
Banned in Australia, briefly, in 1938.[14]
Banned by Australia in 1945 as "a collection of bawdiness, amounting to sex obsession."[15][16]
Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958.[17]

Banned in Australia by the Commonwealth Customs Department in February 1963. The Literature Censorship Board described it as "continually smeared with indecent, offensive and dirty epithets and allusions," but recommended that the book remain available to "the serious minded student or reader." The ban was lifted in May 1966.[18]
Banned in Australia from 1967 until 1973.[10]

column2: The World Is Full of Married Men (1968)
column6: Banned in Australia in 1968.[10]
Banned in Australia in 1969.[10][further explanation needed]

The book was refused classification in 1985 thus making it banned in Australia under the National Classification Code Table 1.(c) for publications that could "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence"[10] [19][20]
An example of a class of books banned in Australia that "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence".[21][22]

Sale and purchase was banned in the Australian State of Queensland. Now available in public libraries and for sale to people 18 years and older. Sale restricted to persons at least 18 years old in the other Australian states.[23]

Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[24] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.
The book was initially restricted in Australia:[25] after review the 2007 edition was banned outright.[22][26][27]

Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[24] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.
Light novel volumes banned in Australia due to depiction which "in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a person who is, or appears to be, a child under 18".[28]
Banned by the authorities in the Austrian territories ruled by the Habsburg monarchy.[29]
All of Marx's works were banned in Austria after the country was annexed by Nazi Germany.[29]
All of Einstein's works published up to 1938 were banned in Austria, after it was annexed by Nazi Germany.[29]

In Austria, the Verbotsgesetz 1947 prohibits the printing of the book. It is illegal to own[citation needed] or distribute existing copies.[30] Following the general prohibition of advocating the Nazi Party or its aims in § 3 and of re-founding Nazi organizations in § 1, § 3 d. of the Verbotsgesetz states: "Whoever publicly or before several people, in printed works, disseminated texts or illustrations requests, encourages or seeks to induce others to commit any of the acts prohibited under § 1 or § 3, especially if for this purpose he glorifies or advertises the aims of the Nazi Party, its institutions or its actions, provided that it does not constitute a more serious criminal offense, will be punished with imprisonment from five to ten years, or up to twenty years if the offender or his actions are especially dangerous."[30]
Currently banned in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.[31]
Banned for blasphemy against Islam. Salman received a fatwa for his alleged blasphemy[32]
Banned in Bangladesh in 1995,[33] though the ban was later lifted in 2000.[34]

Banned in Bangladesh,[35][36] and a few states of India. Other books by her were also banned in Bangladesh or in the Indian state of West Bengal. Amar Meyebela (My Girlhood, 2002), the first volume of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi government in 1999 for "reckless comments" against Islam and the prophet Mohammad.[37] Utal Hawa (Wild Wind), the second part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2002.[38] Ka (Speak up), the third part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi High Court in 2003. Under pressure from Indian Muslim activists, the book, which was published in West Bengal as Dwikhandita, was banned there also; some 3,000 copies were seized immediately.[39] The decision to ban the book was criticised by "a host of authors" in West Bengal,[40] but the ban was not lifted until 2005.[41][42] Sei Sob Ondhokar (Those Dark Days), the fourth part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2004.[43][44]

Banned in Belgium because this satirical novel offended fashion designer Ann Demeulemeester by making derogatory remarks about her personal looks and profession. A court decided the book was an insult to the individual's private life and ordered it to be removed from the stores.[45][46][47]
Banned in Bosnian schools by Carlos Westendorp.[citation needed]
Banned in Brazil by the censorship during the military dictatorship.[48]

column11: This list is incomplete; you can help by adding missing items. (August 2023)

column6: Banned in Pinochet's Chile. The Chilean army publicly burned copies of the book.[59]
Banned in Pinochet's Chile.[60]

Banned in Pinochet's Chile. On November 28, 1986, the Chilean customs authorities seized almost 15,000 copies of Clandestine in Chile, which were later burned by military authorities in Valparaíso.[61]
Banned by government of Second Czechoslovak Republic in 1938.
Banned by government in 1948.[112]
Banned by government of Second Czechoslovak Republic in 1938.
Banned by government in 1948.[112]

column2: A Feast for the Seaweeds (Walimah li A'ashab al-Bahr)
column6: Banned in Egypt and several other Arab states, and even resulted in a belated angry reaction from the clerics of Al-Azhar University upon reprinting in Egypt in the year 2000. The clerics issued a fatwa banning the novel, and accused Haidar of heresy and offending Islam. Al-Azhar University students staged huge protests against the novel, that eventually led to its confiscation.[113][114][115]
Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[32]
Banned by El Salvador for its portrayal of human rights violations.[116]

column2: I Didn't Do It for You: How the World Betrayed a Small African Nation (2005)
column6: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of President Isaias Afewerki.[117][failed verification]
Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for political content.[117][failed verification]
Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of civil liberties under President Isaias Afewerki.[117][failed verification]
Officially banned in France in 1748.[118]

After appearing as a successful serial in the Revue de Paris Gustave Flaubert's Madame Bovary went on trial in France on January 30, 1857, for "offenses against public morals", but did not succeed in court.
French officials banned it for being "obscene".[4]

This book, reviewing recipes for committing suicide, was the cause of a scandal in France in the 1980s, resulting in the enactment of a law prohibiting provocation to commit suicide and propaganda or advertisement of products, objects, or methods for committing suicide.[119] Subsequent reprints were thus illegal. The book was cited by name in the debates of the French National Assembly when examining the bill.[120]

column3: Erwin von Busse under the pseudonym "Granand"
column6: Banned for "indecency" by courts in Berlin and Leipzig[121]
Banned in 1967 in Greece because of its anti-war message.[133]
Banned during the regime of Jorge Ubico along with anti-Hitler writings such as by those of Hermann Rauschning in order to encourage political neutrality in WWII.[134]
Banned in Guatemala because it went against the ruling political leaders.[135]
Banned in Indonesia in 1950, for containing "subversive" material, including an attempt to promote Marxist–Leninist thought and other Communist theories. As of 2006, the ban is still in effect.[136]

Presidential Instruction No. 14/1967 (Inpress No. 14/1967) on Chinese Religion, Beliefs, and Traditions effectively banned any Chinese literature in Indonesia, including the prohibition of Chinese characters.
Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[137]
Banned by the government of Indonesia for subversive and/or anti-government themes.
Banned in Indonesia in 1950, for containing "subversive" material, including an attempt to promote Marxist–Leninist thought and other Communist theories. As of 2006, the ban is still in effect.[136]

Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[137]

Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[32]
Was banned in Iran after men torched its publication house.[138]
Banned by the Irish Parliament for contradicting the teaching of the Anglican Church. Copies of the book were burnt by the public hangman in Dublin.[139]
Banned for obscenity in 1953. The ban was lifted in 1967.[8]
Banned by the Irish Censorship Board for discussing birth control.[140]
The English translations of Sholokhov's work were banned for "indecency".[141]
Elmer Gantry was banned in the Irish Free State.[142]
The first book to be banned by the Irish Free State for alleged "indecency". Republished in 2013.[143]
Suppressed in the Irish Free State.[141]
Suppressed in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education, birth control and open marriages.[141]
Banned in the Irish Free State for advocating sex education for adolescents.[141]
Banned in the Irish Free State.[142]

Banned in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education and Calendar-based contraceptive methods – even though The Laws of Life had been granted a Cum permissu superiorum endorsement by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Westminster.[144]
Banned in the Irish Free State.[141]
Banned in Ireland.[144]
Banned in Ireland.[144]
Banned by the Irish censors for discussing sexuality in rural Ireland.[145]

Banned in Ireland in 1958. The Irish Censorship of Publications Board was not obliged to reveal its reason but it is believed that it was rejected for its critique of Irish republicanism and the Catholic Church, and its depiction of adolescent sexuality.[17]
Banned by Ireland's censorship board in 1960 for its explicit sexual content.[146][147]
Banned in Ireland in 1962 after Archbishop John Charles McQuaid complained personally to Justice Minister Charles Haughey that it "was particularly bad".[147]
Banned in Ireland for obscenity.[148]
Banned in Ireland for its sexual content.[149]

column6: Banned in Fascist Italy because of its antimilitarism (currently not banned).[150]

Banned in Japan (1988–2005) to quell "political threats to boycott Japanese cultural exports", although the pictures were not those of the original version.[152]

On July 12, 2007, the government of Malaysia announced a ban on Spencer's book, citing "confusion and anxiety among the Muslims" as the cause.[154]
The entire trilogy was banned in Malaysia from 2015 for containing "sadistic" material and "threat to morality".[155]
Banned preemptively in Malaysia for blasphemy.[156]

column2: Rebirth: Reformasi, Resistance, and Hope in New Malaysia
column6: Banned for containing insulting elements to the Malaysian coat of arms which is likely to be prejudicial to public order, security, national interest, alarm public opinion and contrary to any law, and therefore is "absolutely prohibited throughout Malaysia".[157]

column2: Gay is OK! A Christian Perspective(2013–2022)
column6: Banned for attempting to promote homosexual culture in Malaysia, which goes against religious and cultural sensitivities in the country.[158] In 2022, the ban was challenged through a judicial review petition in High Court of Kuala Lumpur. The court quashed the ban and ordered the Home Ministry of Malaysia to pay RM 5000 to the author.[159]
Banned for containing pornographic and immoral content.[160] Notably, it was the first Tamil language publication to be banned in the country.

column5: Biography of Hassan II of Morocco
column6: Banned in Morocco. This book is a biography of King Hassan and examines cases of torture, killing, and political imprisonment said to have been carried out by the Moroccan Government at his orders.[161]
Banned in Morocco. This book makes allegedly "defamatory" accusations of corruption against Mohammed VI of Morocco, after investigating the exponential growth of his wealth.[162][163]
Banned for blasphemy against Hindu goddess.
Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[32]

column6: Banned for irredentist views regarding the country's neighbors.[164][failed verification]

Banned in the Netherlands by court order in 2015 as a former spy of Dutch military intelligence claimed she was described falsely in this Srebrenica book.[165] Ban lifted by the Court of Appeal of The Hague in 2016.[166][167]
Banned for being "obscene"; uncensored in 1964.[4]
Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958. It was allowed to be published in New Zealand in 1963.[17]

Initially banned in New Zealand by Office of Film & Literature Classification since it was deemed to be objectionable.[168] In May 2008 an edited version of the book was allowed for sale if sealed and an indication of the censorship classification was displayed.
Banned in New Zealand in 2015; subsequently unrestricted in the same year.[169]
The Christchurch shooter's manifesto was banned shortly after it appeared on the internet in 2019.

Banned in Nigeria because this three-volume memoirs of the former Nigerian president were highly critical of nearly everyone in Nigerian politics. The books were ordered to be seized by the High Court in Nigeria until a libel case had been heard in court.[170]
Sexually explicit.[171]
Sexually explicit.[172]

column2: The Untold Story of Imelda Marcos
column6: Banned in 1972, shortly after the start of the Martial Law period under President Ferdinand Marcos. The "unauthorized" biography was banned for the depiction of First Lady Imelda Marcos' extravagance.[178]

column2: Tawid diwa sa pananagisag ni Bienvenido Lumbera: Ang Bayan, ang Nanunulat at ang Magasing Sagisag sa Imahinatibong Yugto ng Batas Militar 1975–1979
column6: Research on the literary works by Bienvenido Lumbera, who was imprisoned during the Martial Law period under President Ferdinand Marcos. Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government".[179]
Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti-government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[179]

Because this pamphlet published in 1618 was one of the causes of the anti-Jewish riots in Cracow, it was banned by Sigismund III Vasa.[180]
Banned until 1992.[126]

column2: História do Mundo para as Crianças (pt)
column6: The books was banned by the Portuguese government without any clear reason. According to the author, one possible reason was because he was from the "current of thought what claims that the discovery of Brazil happened 'by random'" or by the fact he "have registered the history of the 1600 years cut to the Arabian navy by Vasco da Gama".[181]

column3: Maria Isabel Barreno, Maria Teresa Horta and Maria Velho da Costa
column6: Banned as "pornographic and an offense to public morals"; authors charged with "abuse of the freedom of the press" and "outrage to public decency"; uplifted after the Carnation Revolution in 1974.[182]

column2: The Man Who Wouldn't Stand Up (2012)
column6: Banned in Qatar in 2014 for its depiction of Islam.[184]

Banned in the Roman Empire in the 330s+ for contradicting Trinitarianism. All of Arius writings were ordered burned and Arius exiled, and presumably assassinated for his writings.[186] Banned by the Catholic Church for the next thousand plus years.[citation needed]
In 2013, a Russian court censored the text under the country's 'extremism' laws.[187]
Banned in Tsarist Russia after the Decembrist revolt.[188]
Prohibited by several countries, including Tsarist Russia.[123]
Banned in Soviet Union since 1923 on proposal of Nadezhda Krupskaya. All works were placed on the list of forbidden books and kept in libraries only for restricted, authorized use.[189]
Prohibited by the Tsarist Russian censors.[190]

column2: The Protocols of the Elders of Zion (1903)
column5: A forgery, portraying a Jewish conspiracy to take over the world
column6: Banned in various libraries and many attempts to ban in various nations, such as in Russia.[citation needed]
Banned in the Russian Federation as extremist.[191]

Completed in 1943, Orwell found that no publisher would print the book, due to its criticism of the USSR, an important ally of Britain in the War.[192] Once published, the book was banned in the USSR and other communist countries.[193]

Banned by the Soviet Union[126] in 1950, as Stalin understood that it was a satire based on his leadership. It was not until 1990 that the Soviet Union legalised the book and it was re-released after editing.[194]

Banned in the Soviet Union until 1988 for criticizing life in Russia after the Russian Revolution. When its author, Boris Pasternak, won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1958 he was forced to reject it under government pressure.[126]

column2: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich (1962)
column6: Banned from publication in the Soviet Union in 1964.[136]

After Nikita Khrushchev was removed from power in 1964, all extant and forthcoming works by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn were banned in the Soviet Union. This work details the lives of scientists forced to work in a Stalinist research center.[195]

Banned in the Soviet Union because it went against the image the Soviet Government tried to project of itself and its policies.[196] However, it has been available in the former Soviet Union since at least the 1980s. In 2009, the Education Ministry of Russia added The Gulag Archipelago to the curriculum for high-school students.[197]

Collection of articles, interviews, and documents that explore the various marginal aspects of culture. It was banned in Russia in July 2006 by court order for propaganda of drug use, owing to inclusion of David Woodard's essay "The Ketamine Necromance", after its first and only Russian publication by Ultra.Kultura (Ультра.Культура). All printed copies of that Russian edition were destroyed.
Anthology of essays advocating for neo-Nazi revolution through terrorism. Banned on August 14, 2023.[198]

Banned from distribution within the South Korean military as part of 23 books banned on August 1, 2008 by the South Korean Ministry of National Defense in response to intelligence suggesting a book-distribution campaign to active-duty soldiers by the pro-North Korean Hanchongnyon.[216] The books were classified into three categories: 11 for praise of North Korea, 10 for anti-government/anti-American content, and 2 for anti-capitalism.[217][218]

column2: Respect, Everything A Guy Needs to Know about Sex, Love and Consent

Voltaire's entire body of work was banned by the Bourbon Monarchy of Spain, after it was condemned by the Spanish Inquisition.[222]
All of Blasco Ibáñez's books were banned by the Franco government in 1939.[223]

column2: A Short History of the World
column6: An expanded, Spanish-language translation of A Short History of the World, discussing recent world events, was banned by Spanish censors in 1940. This edition of A Short History was not published in Spain until 1963. In two 1948 reports, Spanish censors gave a list of objections to the books's publication. These were that the book "shows socialist inclinations, attacks the Catholic Church, gives a twisted interpretation of the Spanish Civil War and the Spanish National Movement, and contains 'tortuous concepts'."[224]
The complete 1945 Spanish-language translation of Ulysses was suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1962.[225]
Banned in Francoist Spain.[129]
Banned in Francoist Spain for its support of the Republican faction during the Spanish Civil War.[226]
Suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1968.[227]
Banned until 1954; published in Argentina.[228]
Banned in Francoist Spain for criticizing Christianity, and for mentioning the Bombing of Guernica by the Axis air forces.[229]
Banned in Francoist Spain because of its strong criticism of the Nationalist Faction's actions during the Spanish Civil War.[230]
Banned in Francoist Spain for its advocacy of feminism.[231]
Banned by censors of Francoist Spain.[232]
Banned by censors of Francoist Spain for its negative depiction of the Nationalist Faction during the Civil War, and its critique of the Franco regime.[233]
Banned briefly in Spain.[234]

Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[32]

"Denounced by the Communists and Nationalists alike, Mr. Shen saw his writings banned in Taiwan, while mainland China publishing houses burned his books and destroyed printing plates for his novels."[235]
Banned in Thailand in 2006 for violating the country's lese-majesté rules through its discussion of the murder of Thailand's king in 1946.[236][further explanation needed]
Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[32]
Banned in Thailand for its criticism of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.[237]

column2: Rama X: The Thai Monarchy under King Vajiralongkorn (2006)
column6: Banned in Thailand for its criticism of King Vajiralongkorn.[238]

In 2002, the novel was banned in the schools of the United Arab Emirates, because it contained text or images that would go against Islamic values, most notably an anthropomorphic, talking pig as the leader of the farm. However, the ban is no longer enforced and has been recently lifted.[136]
Banned in the Kingdom of England for political reasons.[239]

column2: Fanny Hill or Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure
column6: Banned in the UK till after the Second World War.[240]
Banned in the UK and author charged with treason for supporting the French Revolution.[133]

column3: Rose Laure Allatini (under the pseudonym A. T. Fitzroy)
column6: Banned under the UK's Defence of the Realm Act for criticizing Britain's involvement in World War I, and for sympathetically depicting male homosexuality.[242]
Banned in the UK until 1936.[243][244]
Banned in the United Kingdom for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1960. [245]
Banned in the UK in 1928 for its lesbian theme; republished in 1949.[246]
Proscuted in 1934 after Hanley's publisher Boriswood lost a court case against a charge of obscenity.[247] Reprinted in 1992 by Penguin Books and André Deutsch.
Banned for being "obscene".[4]
Banned in Soho for frank depictions of taboo subjects, such as drug use, street violence, homosexuality, gender identity and domestic violence.[249]
Banned in the UK 1985–1988 for revealing secrets. Wright was a former MI5 intelligence officer and his book was banned before it was even published in 1987.[250][251]

Banned in England in 1991 where it was found obscene; it is currently the last book to be banned in the UK. The judge ordered the remaining print run to be destroyed. The ban was lifted in the Appeal Court in July 1992 but the book remains out of print.[252]
Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[253][254]
Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[253][254]

column2: Put 'Em Down. Take 'Em Out. Knife Fighting Techniques From Folsom Prison
column6: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[253][254]
Banned from US mail under the Federal Anti-Obscenity Act (Comstock Law) of 1873, which banned the sending or receiving of works containing "obscene", "filthy", or "inappropriate" material.[133]

Banned from US mail under the Federal Anti-Obscenity Act (Comstock Law) of 1873, which banned the sending or receiving of works containing "obscene", "filthy", or "inappropriate" material. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[255][256][133]

column2: The Meritorious Price of Our Redemption (1650)
column6: The first book banned in the New World. Pynchon, a prominent leader of the Massachusetts Bay Colony who, in 1636, founded the City of Springfield, Massachusetts, wrote this explicit critique of Puritanism, published in London in 1650. That year, several copies made their way back to the New World. Pynchon, who resided in Springfield, was unaware that his book suffered the New World's first book burning, on the Boston Common. Accused of heresy by the Massachusetts General Court, Pynchon quietly transferred ownership of the Connecticut River Valley's largest land-holdings to his son, and then suffered indignities as he left the New World for England. It was the first work banned in Boston.[257]

column2: Moll Flanders or The Fortunes and Misfortunes of the Famous Moll Flanders (1722)
column6: Banned from US mail under the Federal Anti-Obscenity Act (Comstock Law) of 1873, which banned the sending or receiving of works containing "obscene", "filthy", or "inappropriate" material. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[255][256][258]

column2: Fanny Hill or Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure
column6: Banned in the US in 1821 for obscenity, then again in 1963. This was the last book ever banned by the US government. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[255][256][127] See also Memoirs v. Massachusetts.
Seized by US Customs in 1930 for obscenity. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[255][256][133]

Banned in the Confederate States during the Civil War because of its anti-slavery content. In 1852, Uncle Tom's Cabin was banned in Russia in the reign of Nicholas I because of the idea of equality it presented, and for its "undermining religious ideals".[136]

Banned in Boston, Massachusetts, Kansas City, Missouri, Camden, New Jersey, and other US cities, this novel by Sinclair focused on religiosity and hypocrisy in the United States during the 1920s by depicting a preacher (the Reverend Dr. Elmer Gantry) as a protagonist who preferred easy money, alcohol, and "enticing young girls" to saving souls, while converting a traveling tent revival crusade into a profitable and permanent evangelical church and radio empire for his employers. Elmer Gantry also widely denounced from pulpits across the United States at the time of its initial publication. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[255][256][259][260]
Temporarily banned in the United States for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1959.[clarification needed][8]

Banned in the US in the 1930s until the early 1960s, seized by US Customs for sexually explicit content and vulgarity. The rest of Miller's work was also banned by the US.[261] Also banned in South Africa until the late 1980s.[262]
Was temporarily banned in many places in the US. In the state of California in which it was partially set, it was banned for its alleged unflattering portrayal of residents of the area.[263]
Banned in fourteen states in the US. Ban was lifted by an appeals court judge.[15][16]
Banned in the state of New York by the Supreme Court.[264]
Copies of the first edition seized by San Francisco Customs for obscenity in March 1957; after trial, obscenity charges were dismissed.[265]
Banned by Boston courts in 1962 for obscenity, but that decision was reversed in 1966 by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.[266]
Banned in Tucson, Arizona.[267]

column2: United States – Vietnam Relations, 1945–1967: A Study Prepared by the Department of Defense (1971)
column3: Robert McNamara and the United States Department of Defense
column6: Also known as the Pentagon Papers. US President Nixon attempted to suspend publication of classified information. The restraint was lifted by the US Supreme Court in a 6–3 decision.[268] See also New York Times Co. v. United States.

An injunction was issued by a US District Court in Nevada under 26 U.S.C. § 7408 against Irwin Schiff and associates Cynthia Neun and Lawrence Cohen against the sale of this book by those persons as the court found that the information it contains is fraudulent.[269]

column3: Army Reserve Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer
column6: In September 2010 the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) overrode the Army's January approval for publication. The DoD then purchased and destroyed all 9,500 first edition copies, citing concerns that it contained classified information which could damage national security. The publisher, St. Martin's Press,[270] in conjunction with the DoD created a second, redacted edition; which contains blacked out words, lines, paragraphs, and portions of the index.[271]
Author in exile since 1994 and all his works are banned for being critical of the government.[272][273][274]
Vietnamese translations are banned[275][276] on the grounds of "promoting false socialism ideology" [277]
The book was unable to get certification for publication thus making it banned in Vietnam [278]

column2: "Mourning Headband for Hue: An Account of the Battle for Hue, Vietnam 1968"
column6: The book was banned for its criticism of the actions of the national liberation front and for acknowledging the 1968 massacre of 6000 civilians in Huế
Banned in Vietnam for criticism on the political party in control.[279]
Banned in Vietnam for criticism of the Vietnamese Communist Party.[280][281][282]

column2: Politics for Everyone (Chính Trị Bình Dân)
column6: Banned in Vietnam on the grounds of political sensitivity.[283][284][285]
Banned due to criticism of the socialist state, especially the planned economy which would inevitably lead to totalitarianism. [286][287]

The author talked about his experience being imprisoned in a "Vietnamese Gulag" for "Anti-revolutionary propaganda"[288] The book was banned with all copies ordered to be destroyed following the Decision No. 395 Regulation of the then Ministry of Culture and Information for violating Clauses 1 and 2 of the Article 33, Publishing Law. Which prohibits works criticising the Vietnamese Communist Party and propaganda going against the interests of the state. [289][290][291]

Due to publications within Vietnam had refused to publish, the author decided to print himself and released it on Amazon. Although it has not been officially banned, the Vietnamese Government had seized and question those who had them.[292][293][294][295] This book was considered to be significant as it has provided insights that scholars had never seen before, while it had received a lot of criticism from Vietnamese state media.[296][297]

column2: A Dusty Wind (Một Cơn Gió Bụi)
column6: Banned in Vietnam for being "inappropriate, not objective, and containing unverified information" thus violating the Vietnamese Publishing Law, which tends to happen to the biographies of historical characters deemed to be "controversial"[Note 1] by the government.[298][299][300]

column2: The Nickel-Plated-Feet Gang During the Occupation (Les Pieds nickelés dans le maquis)
column6: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1945.[301]
Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1951.[301][citation needed]

column2: The New Class: An Analysis of the Communist System (1957)
column6: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1957; author sentenced for enemy propaganda to seven years in prison, prolonged to 13 years in 1962.[302]
In 1963 in Yugoslavia withdrawn by the publisher (Nolit) at request of SDB officials.[302]
Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1966, at request of Mirko Tepavac, because "some definitions can cause disturbance among citizens".[302]

column2: A Message to Man and Humanity
column6: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1967 for "false and wicked claims, and enemy propaganda that supports pro-Chinese politics".[302]
Withdrawn from sales and destroyed after the decision of the Municipal Committee of the League of Communists of Kraljevo in Kraljevo, Yugoslavia in 1967.[302]
Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1983; republished in 2004.[301]
Withdrawn from print in Yugoslavia in 1964 because it contained stories by Dragiša Vasić.[302]
Written in Tuzla prison in 1984. Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1984; republished in 2005.[301]
